speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these bleeding episodes started? Were they sudden or did they come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started a few months ago, I think. My mom said it was after I fell off my bike, and then it just kept happening more and more."

speaker: Doctor
text: When did the first episode occur? Was it something that happened suddenly or did it start with a few minor incidents that gradually increased in frequency and severity?

speaker: Patient
text: "Um, I don't know... I think it started after I fell off my bike, but sometimes it happens when I'm playing with my friends or even just running around outside. My mom says it's getting worse."

speaker: Doctor
text: So, the first episode occurred about 3 months ago, and initially, it was a minor nosebleed that stopped on its own. However, over the past few weeks, the bleeding episodes have become more frequent and severe.

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really know why it's getting worse. Sometimes I get a nosebleed and it stops, but then I'll get a few more later that day. It feels like it's getting more and more... unpredictable."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the frequency and severity of these recent bleeding episodes? Are they happening at the same time every day, or are they somewhat unpredictable?

speaker: Patient
text: "They happen sometimes, like after I play or run around, and sometimes they just happen out of nowhere. It's like my nosebleeds are getting more and more... unpredictable, like they don't want to stop. My mom is always helping me, and we have to stop the bleeding with gauze before I can do anything else."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities and any potential triggers that you think might be causing these bleeding episodes? For instance, do you engage in any strenuous physical activities, or are you exposed to cold air or dry environments that might dry out your nasal passages?

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh-huh... I like to play outside with my friends, and we run around a lot. Sometimes we climb trees or play on the swings, and I think that might be when it happens. I don't know, though... I feel like it could be anything, like my nose just gets too big or something."

speaker: Doctor
text:
How often are these bleeding episodes occurring now? Are they happening multiple times a day, or can you go several days without an episode?



Also, have you noticed any other symptoms in addition to these bleeding episodes, such as fever, fatigue, or swelling in your face or neck?



Can you tell me more about your diet and any medications you might be taking that could be contributing to these bleeding episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, I get a nosebleed sometimes, like 2-3 times a day. My mom helps me stop the bleeding, and we use gauze to make it stop. It's really annoying, and I don't like getting it all over my face."

speaker: Doctor
text: So, it seems like the bleeding episodes have escalated over time, and you're concerned about their frequency and severity. Can you tell me about your lifestyle and habits - do you have any siblings or family members with similar symptoms, and have you recently traveled to any new places or been exposed to new environments?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I have a big brother, and he's always getting boo-boos, but I don't think he's ever had nosebleeds like this before. And, um, I went to school for the first time last month, and I remember getting a lot of stuff in my face when I was playing on the swings, but that might not have anything to do with it."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns? Do you have trouble sleeping at night, or do you wake up frequently throughout the day?



Also, have you noticed any specific foods or drinks that seem to trigger your bleeding episodes, such as citrus fruits, spicy foods, or caffeine?



Have you had any recent exposure to your family members, such as close contact with a sibling or parent, that might be contributing to your symptoms?



Can you show me the exact location of the petechiae on your body, so I can get a better understanding of their distribution and severity?



How would you rate the severity of your symptoms on a scale of 1-10, with 1 being mild and 10 being severe?



Also, have you experienced any recent trauma, falls, or injuries that might have triggered these bleeding episodes?



REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh... I think they're all over my arms and legs, but sometimes they can be on my face too. My mom says it's like little dots or spots, but I don't really know how to explain it."

speaker: Doctor
text:
